stem: Ten minutes after a blood transfusion begins, the client reports back pain and chills. The nurse observes the client is restless and has a fever. Which action should the nurse take first?

options.text: Notify the blood bank and healthcare provider.
Infuse normal saline through the same tubing.

rationale.correct: At the first sign of any transfusion reaction (fever, chills, back pain), the nurse must STOP the transfusion to prevent further exposure to the offending blood product. This is the absolute first priority.
rationale.incorrect: Notification and medications follow the stoppage of the blood. Infusing saline through the SAME tubing is incorrect because the tubing contains blood that would be pushed into the client; a new saline line should be used.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: Choosing "Notify the blood bank and healthcare provider." represents a misinterpretation of the gathered cues or a failure to prioritize physiological needs.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: The inclusion of "Stop the transfusion immediately." is necessary to address the underlying physiological instability identified during assessment.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: In this specific NGN scenario, "Infuse normal saline through the same tubing." is incorrect as it introduces clinical risk or deviates from standard triage logic.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: In this specific NGN scenario, "Administer diphenhydramine as prescribed." is incorrect as it introduces clinical risk or deviates from standard triage logic.

clinicalPearls: Most reactions occur in the first 15 minutes.
Always keep the IV line open with fresh saline and new tubing.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: When stopping a transfusion, always REJECT any option that suggests using the same tubing to flush or infuse saline.

mnemonic.title: S-N-S
mnemonic.expansion: Stop blood, Normal saline (New tubing), Send bag to lab.

reviewUnits.heading: Transfusion Reactions
reviewUnits.body: Hemolytic reactions are medical emergencies caused by ABO incompatibility.
